docs.lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of President George W. Bush's message to Congress last night, as recorded by The New York Times: Thank you. Mr. Speaker, Mr. Vice President, members of Congress: It's a great privilege to be here to outline a new budget and a new approach for governing our great country. I thank you for your invitation to speak here tonight. I know Congress had to formally invite me. And it could have been a close vote. So, Mr. Vice President, I appreciate you being here to break the tie. I want to thank so many of you who have accepted my invitation to come to the White House to discuss important issues. We're off to a good start. I will continue to meet with you and ask for your input. You have been kind and candid, and I thank you for making a new president feel welcome.

headline.main: Transcript of President Bush's Message to Congress on His Budget Proposal

docs.abstract: Transcript of Pres George W Bush's message to Congress

docs.lead_paragraph: GLORIA Nelson, a crossing guard at Public School 92 in Corona, had strolled past the Astoria Boulevard salon four or five times, intrigued by the possibilities but too shy to walk in the door. Then one Thursday afternoon, Ms. Nelson screwed up her courage and entered the world of J. C.'s Hair Extraordinaire East. There, in the East Elmhurst beauty salon with the apricot-colored walls and the buzz of transformation and dreams, Ms. Nelson told J. C. Harris, the owner, that she was ready for a change.

headline.main: Under the Dryers, a Community's Heart

docs.abstract: Article describes sense of community within J C's Hair Extraordinaire East, beauty salon in East Elmhurst section of Queens, NYC, owned by J C Harris; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: On the afternoon of Feb. 14, an express courier truck arrived at an Atlanta fertility clinic to make an unusual pickup. Waiting for the driver, frozen inside a thermos of liquid nitrogen, was the promise of human life: 12 fertilized embryos, the genetic offspring of Susanne and Bob Gray. For the Grays, now parents of four, the shipment represented an escape from a moral quandary. Their embryos, left over from fertility treatment that resulted in the birth of twins, had sat in cold storage for years while the Grays, Christians who describe themselves as deeply religious, agonized over what to do with them.

headline.main: Some See New Route to Adoption In Clinics Full of Frozen Embryos

docs.abstract: Fate of tens of thousands of leftover human embryos weighs heavily on minds of fertility doctors and their patients; embryos are not only potential babies, they are also source of embryonic stem cells; scientists say they hold great promise for curing human disease because they can grow into many types of cells; this research is controversial, because it requires that embryos be destroyed; Pres Bush is considering whether to permit federal financing for stem cell studies; already some scientists are trying to negotiate with fertility doctors to obtain excess embryos; some fertility programs are quietly offering couples option of putting their excess embryos up for adoption, either openly or anonymously; embryo adoption is inexpensive alternative for couples who cannot conceive using their own eggs or sperm; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The statistics tell the damning story of this city: nearly 80 percent of all babies born in 1998 had single mothers, double the national average and 10 times the state average. A quarter of all births were to teenage mothers, and a quarter of those teenagers had given birth before. In each category, Hartford topped a list of 55 cities included in a nationwide child health report published Tuesday by the Annie E. Casey Foundation in Baltimore. The survey, which also included statistics for New York City, New York State and New Jersey, further illustrated Hartford's decade-long struggle to overcome social and economic problems that public health experts and elected officials have not been able to solve.

headline.main: Hartford Worst in National Study Of Births to Unmarried Mothers

docs.abstract: Study shows that Hartford, Conn, leads nation in number of births to unmarried mothers, with nearly 80 percent of all babies born in 1998 having single mothers--double national average and 10 times state average; shows that quarter of all births were to teen-age mothers, and a quarter of those teenagers had given birth before; nationwide health report published by Annie E Casey Foundation in Baltimore illustrates Hartford's decade-long struggle to overcome social and economic problems that public health experts and elected officials have not been able to solve (M)
